Award.AwardTitle: Modeling the Cosmic Melting Pots in the Outskirts of Galaxies and Galaxy Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the growth of galaxies and galaxy clusters is one of the most significant outstanding problems in our knowledge of the universe. On the largest scales, the universe has a filamentary structure, with gas and dark matter interweaving in a series of threads. The gradual flow and build-up of gas along this "cosmic web" ultimately leads to the formation of protogalaxies and protoclusters. Despite this, the precise manner in which galaxies and their clusters eventually form remains poorly understood. A breakthrough step, enabled by this research, is to connect and synthesize our knowledge of the gas in the outskirts of galaxies with that in galaxy clusters.

This program will address a number of critical questions regarding the structure and flow of gas by using a suite of high-resolution cosmological simulations. The PI will principally use the Adaptive Refinement Tree (ART) code, but will also compare the results of these simulations with detailed multi-wavelength observations of clusters and the circumgalactic medium. The work will lead to new insights into the baryon budgets in galaxies and clusters, the impact of galactic feedback on extended halo gas, the environmental dependence of galaxy evolution, and the quenching of star formation in galaxies.

The PI will also develop a hands-on computational astrophysics curriculum to expand minority involvement in computational science, in collaboration with the Science, Technology, and Research Scholars (STARS) program at Yale University. Furthermore, the data products of the simulations will be made available via online publicly-accessible databases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Galaxy clusters are the largest gravitationally collapsed objects in the universe, which are composed mostly of dark matter and dark energy. However, in order to use these complex systems as a probe of elusive dark matter and dark energy, it is important to advance our understanding of the X-ray emitting gas permeating through the intergalactic space within galaxy clusters, which can be probed using X-ray telescopes. With support from NSF, the Yale Computational Cosmology group led by Daisuke Nagai (PI) has studied how galaxy clusters form and grow in the universe. Specifically, the team has developed the state-of-the-art supercomputer simulations of galaxy cluster formation. By analyzing the outputs of these simulations, the Nagai's research team has discovered that the outer envelope of galaxy clusters is a promising new platform for studying the inner workings of our cosmos, from the smallest constituents of matter to the largest known structures. Their work has significantly improved our understanding of the hot gas in the outer envelope of galaxy clusters, provided physical insights into several puzzling observational results obtained by Chandra, Hitomi, Suzaku and XMM-Newton X-ray space observatories, and helped define new challenges and scientific goals for future X-ray space missions. 

Beyond his own research, Nagai is also committed to training the next-generation of computational and data scientists who will contribute to the emerging data-driven society. His approach is to involve students into cutting-edge research in computational cosmology and help them learn how to integrate a variety of skills for tackling complex real-world problems. He has also been teaching a course entitled "Computing for Scientific Research", which introduces basic computational tools and techniques utilized in science and engineering research through hands-on research-based projects. Since 2015, he has been serving as one of the inaugural academic co-directors of the Yale Center for Research Computing to help set and implement its academic and strategic directions.
